subject: Hong Kong is reportedly studying a curfew to contain protest violence, according to local press Sing Tao
content:
• "It is reported that the Hong Kong Government is studying various more effective schemes to "stop the storm." Some government officials believe that in various legal tools, the curfew order does not require the use of the Emergency Law. It is a more feasible method, and its role is like a cooling-off period to reduce crowds."

Link to article
analysis_details: • In accordance with section 31 of the Public Order Ordinance, the Chief Executive may, if he is satisfied that there is a need for public order, may use a ban to direct each person to remain in the specified area and time for the period specified in the order. Until the Chief Executive first revokes the curfew. Anyone who contravenes a curfew is guilty of an offence and is liable on conviction to imprisonment for two years; a person such as a police or other disciplined force is not subject to a ban on duty or on his way to and from duty. (Sing Tao)

subject: DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
3rd October 2019

ASIA-PAC

US

US President Trump blames recent underperformance in the stock market on impeachment talk. (Newswires)

US Speaker of the House Pelosi said House on a path to say "yes" to the USMCA. (Newswires)

US House Oversight Committee Chairman Cummings has notified of his intention to subpoena the White House for Ukraine records on Friday, in the event they do not voluntarily provide this. (NYT)

Fed's Williams (Voter) said monetary policy is in the right place, financial stability risks are not huge although heavy corporate borrowing could amplify a downturn, labour market is still very strong and in a world with low interest rates, aid from the fiscal side is important. William said if you look in the rear view the US economy is very strong, adding the outlook for US economy is a mixed picture, mentions a lot of uncertainties, trade effects are relatively modest. (Newswires)

Fed’s Barkin (Non-Voter) said his posture is very balanced on the rate outlook; expects a lot of information before the next FOMC meeting, businesses remain challenged to pass along pricing and that manufacturing weakness is due to trade uncertainties. (Newswires)

DATA RECAP

- US ADP National Employment* (Sep) 135.0k vs. Exp. 140.0k (Prev. 195.0k, Rev. 157.0k) (Newswires)

UK/EU

USTR Official said the US will impose retaliatory tariffs of 10% on EU aircraft (not applicable to aircraft parts), 25% on EU agriculture and industrial goods, USTR will announce the list of EU goods on Wednesday that will be subjected, intended to take place on October 18th. USTR Official decline to provide a total amount of imports that will be affected. US would be ready to respond if the EU invokes further than the WTO tariff authority in retaliation. US is willing to negotiate with the EU to settle aircraft case, but past EU offers have not been adequate; hopes imposing these tariffs will lead to a negotiated settlement. The US has requested an emergency meeting for mid-October of the WTO dispute body, a signal of fast movements for tariffs on EU goods, according to sources. (Newswires)

WTO awarded US right to target USD 7.5bln of EU imports with trade sanctions in the Airbus subsidy case. French Finance Minister Le Maire earlier said the EU is prepared to respond firmly with European partners in the event of US sanctions. (Newswires)

EU Commission welcomed UK PM Johnson's determination to advance Brexit talks, Commission President Juncker acknowledged the postie advances, notably to the regulatory alignment for control of goods entering Northern Ireland from Britain but added will need further work in coming days. Brussels still believe a new Brexit extension is the most likely outcome, according to BBC's Katya Adler. Brussels reiterated that customs remain a sticking point. EU Brexit Negotiator says, after receiving the UK backstop proposal, that there is progress, but a lot of work still needs to be done. EU believe PM Johnson is willing to negotiate further in Brussels, caveated with it does not mean EU thinks a deal is likely by Mid October. An EU sources also noted that the proposal “is a million miles away from being acceptable”, Sky News’ Lewis Goodall tweeted. (Twitter)

EU sources said the only likely option for a Brexit deal before 31 October is a return to a NI only backstop, else there is likely to be a delay which the EU would agree to. (Newswires)

Irish PM Varadkar told UK PM Johnson that the proposals did not fully meet the objectives of the backstop but would study the proposals further and would consult with the EU, according to a spokesperson. Irish PM said he wants a deal agreed and ratified and will speak to Johnson again next week. (Newswires)

ECB’s De Guindos said it is often said that low or negative interest rates inflate prices as investors search for yield and take on more credit and duration risk. (Newswires)

German Economy Minister said that now is not the correct time to be discussing the end of the 'black zero' budget policy. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Saudi Aramco tells Wall Street underwriters IPO will proceed despite drone strikes as oil production returns to normal, according to Fox's Gasparino. (Newswires)

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said the message here is OPEC and OPEC+ have become a reliable and dependable source of supply. The world should not panic and the Saudis have shown beyond any reasonable doubt that this resource, its supply is guaranteed. (Newswires)

Libya are currently producing 1.3mln BPD of oil (Prev. 1.2mln BPD), Libya NOC. (Newswires)

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 3.104M vs. Exp. 1.567M (Prev. 2.412M) (Newswires) US EIA Weekly Crude Production 12.4M (Prev. 12.5M); 100k barrels, -0.80%

Chile Finance Minister estimates 2020 copper price at USD 2.85/lb. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 -1.8% at 2888, NASDAQ-100 -1.7% at 7551, Dow Jones -1.9% at 26079 * S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -1.8%, Consumer Staples -1.9%, Energy -2.6%, Financials -2.1%, Health Care -1.5%, Industrials -2%, Information Technology -2%, Materials -1.9%, Telecommunication Services -1.4%, Utilities -1.3%. STOCK SPECIFICS: Retail stocks (LB, KSS, CPRI, M, BBY) printed chunky losses amid growing expectations of manufacturing weakness seeping into the thus-far generally resilient consumer, historically noted as the last domino to fall. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) bucked the trend and traded in the green after initial opioid settlement payments indicated less severe liability management going forward; Humana (HUM) was another related name in the green. Ford (F) feel after disappointing September vehicle sales. Delta Air Lines (DAL) tumbled as it announced increased unit costs for its third quarter ahead of its official report on October 10th, weighing on competitors such as United Airlines (UAL) and American Airlines (AAL). Paychex (PAYX) and Lennar (LEN) both outperformed after strong earnings reports, although the latter did fluctuate during its conference call over warnings of labour shortages. Goldminers (NEM, GOLD) benefitted from the bullion gains on declining risk appetite. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Monster Energy (MNST) gapped lower on the open after downgrades at Bernstein and Guggenheim, respectively. E-Trade (ETFC) traded lower again following a double downgrade at Barclays and no doubt helped by TD Ameritrade (AMTD) joining Charles Schwab (SCHW) in cutting trading commission to 0%.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 15+ HIGHER AT 131-04+: The TPLEX rallied again as risk appetite continued to dwindle due to persistent global weakness in manufacturing, with added strain of the WTO clearing the way for a new US-EU trade front. The curve continued to bull steepen throughout the session with CME market expectations for an October rate cut rising to 77%, compared to 55% priced in the wake of Tuesday’s ISM manufacturing data and 40% before it. Participants now wait crucially on Thursday’s ISM non-manufacturing and Friday’s payrolls to see whether they echo the ominous tone from the manufacturing sector. At settlement the 2-year yield fell by 8bps, and the long bond being little changed.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 2nd October 2019: Stock tumble continues whilst WTO ruling only adds to pessimism
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 2nd October 2019: Stock tumble continues whilst WTO ruling only adds to pessimism

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude down.

* REAR VIEW: WTO rules US can tariff USD 7.5bln worth of EU goods; ADP supports thesis of a slowing labour market; EU not impressed by UK Brexit proposal

* UPCOMING: Data: Japanese Services PMI, UK & EZ Services and Composite PMIs, US Initial Jobless Claims, Composite & Services PMIs and ISM Non-manufacturing PMI. Speakers: BoJ’s Funo, ECB’s de Guindos, de Cos and Rehn, Fed’s Evans, Quarles, Mester, Kaplan and Clarida, Riksbank’s Olhsson, Skingsley and Ingves. Events: Chinese Golden Week and German Unity Day.

 

* MARKET WRAP: The dial did not change on Wednesday as major bourses accumulated further losses - with a (baker’s) dozen of S&P 500 constituents in the green - as growth concerns continued to ring loud post Tuesday’s abysmal manufacturing ISMs. The WTO ruling in the US’ favour for USD 7.5bln of tariffs on EU goods, an ADP figure supporting a slowing labour market thesis and a noisy Brexit and geopolitical backdrop did not provide any support for risk assets; CME market pricing for an October rate cut rose to 77%, for reference, it stood at 40% before the US ISM manufacturing on Tuesday. XAU, Yen and Treasuries saw inflows whilst all equity sectors traded in the red with desks noting outright liquidation rather than sector rotation. The bearish EIA report exacerbated the losses in energy markets, too. Thursday’s ISM non-manufacturing and Friday’s payrolls report will be critical for the market in whether support can be found going into the weekend and ahead of the high-level US-China trade talks beginning on October 10th.

* US ADP NATIONAL EMPLOYMENT: ADP’s private survey of payroll growth showed 135k additions in September, short of the consensus 140k, while the prior was revised lower from 190k to 157k. The average monthly job growth for the past three months is at 145k, last year the average stood at 214k for the same period, showing signs the job market is showing, ADP said . Pantheon Macroeconomics stated it is not as soft as it seems, however, as it incorporates official payroll data from the prior month, which only saw a rise of 96K, adding constraint to the September ADP headline print. PM note today’s data does not change their forecast for Non-Farm Payrolls on Friday, adding, “The downshift in labor demand in all the surveys we follow suggest job gains will be down to just 50-to-75K by the turn of next year.” It also states that with the lower revisions has no implication for revisions to the official data on Friday.

* WTO: As had been expected, the World Trading Organisation ruled that the US can slap tariffs of up to USD 7.5bln on EU imports, due to the illegal subsidies given to Airbus (AIR FP). Reports have suggested that the US has prepared a list of USD 21bln worth of European goods which could be subject to US tariffs; the EU has its own list of USD 20bln US exports to target. The EU immediately responded, saying US imposition of measures on EU imports over Airbus subsidies would be short sighted and counter-productive, adding that it was seeking fair settlement in the cases of aircraft subsidies, but stated that it would respond with measures in the Boeing case if the US pursued tariffs against Airbus. There were later reports that the US had requested an emergency meeting for mid-October of the WTO dispute body, a signal that it is moving fast to implement tariffs. The WTO is also set to rule on a separate EU case against US subsidies to Boeing (BA), which have also previously been judged as illegal; that decision is due in the first half of 2020, and will determine the value of exports the EU can slap tariffs on.

* FED: Fed’s Williams (voter) said the outlook for the economy was mixed, though the economy seemed in a favourable place. Williams took note that trade uncertainty and geopolitical risks were creating crosscurrents as the Fed tries to keep the economy in ‘roughly the same place’. Williams again warned about reading too much into yield curves, but suggested the flatness showed investor uncertainty. He felt the labour market was strong, and that the economy was in a positive place. Williams intimated that he was keeping an eye on money markets, which had kept him up at night. Looking ahead, Williams said that during a recession, actions from the Fed playbook would include rate cuts, forward guidance and bond purchases. Fed’s Barkin (non-voter) said his posture on the rate outlook was very balanced; he expects a lot of information before the next FOMC meeting, appearing to suggest he will approach in a data-dependent mindset. Barkin also noted that businesses remain challenged to pass along pricing, and that manufacturing weakness was a result of trade uncertainties.

* ECB: ECB's De Guindos argued that low or negative interest rates inflate prices as investors search for yield and take on more credit and duration risk. He said the current interest rate environment had various implications for the banking sector, noting that banks have benefited, and will continue to benefit from the lower credit risk for borrowers, as well as from higher asset valuations associated with lower interest rates and better macroeconomic outcomes. However, De Guindos said that negative rates policy also entails costs for banks, and these could increase the longer negative rates are in place; the lower policy rates are set, the larger the amount of excess liquidity held by banks.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 15+ HIGHER AT 131-04+: The TPLEX rallied again as risk appetite continued to dwindle due to persistent global weakness in manufacturing, with added strain of the WTO clearing the way for a new US-EU trade front. The curve continued to bull steepen throughout the session with CME market expectations for an October rate cut rising to 77%, compared to 55% priced in the wake of Tuesday’s ISM manufacturing data and 40% before it. Participants now wait crucially on Thursday’s ISM non-manufacturing and Friday’s payrolls to see whether they echo the ominous tone from the manufacturing sector. At settlement the 2-year yield fell by 8bps, and the long bond being little changed.

* WTI (X9) SETTLED USD 0.98 LOWER AT USD 52.64/BBL; BRENT (Z9) SETTLED USD 1.20 LOWER AT USD 57.69/BBL. With risk assets continuing to suffer in wake of Tuesday's grim manufacturing ISM, energy futures were already trundling on the downside before accelerating into a sharp leg lower as the EIA weekly inventory data reversed bullish support after the surprise draw reported in the API data on Tuesday. The EIA reported crude stock building 3.1mln bbls (exp. 1.6mln bbls, and contrary to the API reporting a 5.6mln bbl draw). Products were more price supportive; gasoline saw a surprise draw of 0.2mln bbls, whilst distillates drew more than expected at 2.4mln bbls. Elsewhere in the report, net imports were little changed, US production ticked down to 12.4mln BPD (from 12.5mln BPD) and refinery utilisation fell by 3.4% (exp. -0.5%). As Saudi production concerns seemingly subside, the crude market is again fixated on its bearish direction in the overhang of Tuesday’s dismal manufacturing PMIs (globally) exacerbating demand concerns for energy (excluding Middle East conflict and a US-China trade truce); It is worth noting that next week will see US/China trade talks, so focus may shift back to the demand side, especially if negotiators strike a constructive tone), analysts are struggling to identify near-term bullish catalysts for crude benchmarks. Analysts aren’t decided on the downward price trend, however, for example Citi’s analysts say, “the expanded current supply/demand deficit off the Saudi production losses argues strongly against complacency regarding supply or a bearish price view,” with the question begging if whether the geopolitical risk premium needs revaluating on potential for more oil infrastructure attacks in the Middle East.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 -1.8% at 2888, NASDAQ-100 -1.7% at 7551, Dow Jones -1.9% at 26079

* S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -1.8%, Consumer Staples -1.9%, Energy -2.6%, Financials -2.1%, Health Care -1.5%, Industrials -2%, Information Technology -2%, Materials -1.9%, Telecommunication Services -1.4%, Utilities -1.3%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Retail stocks (LB, KSS, CPRI, M, BBY) printed chunky losses amid growing expectations of manufacturing weakness seeping into the thus-far generally resilient consumer, historically noted as the last domino to fall. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) bucked the trend and traded in the green after initial opioid settlement payments indicated less severe liability management going forward; Humana (HUM) was another related name in the green. Ford (F) feel after disappointing September vehicle sales. Delta Air Lines (DAL) tumbled as it announced increased unit costs for its third quarter ahead of its official report on October 10th, weighing on competitors such as United Airlines (UAL) and American Airlines (AAL). Paychex (PAYX) and Lennar (LEN) both outperformed after strong earnings reports, although the latter did fluctuate during its conference call over warnings of labour shortages. Goldminers (NEM, GOLD) benefitted from the bullion gains on declining risk appetite. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Monster Energy (MNST) gapped lower on the open after downgrades at Bernstein and Guggenheim, respectively. E-Trade (ETFC) traded lower again following a double downgrade at Barclays and no doubt helped by TD Ameritrade (AMTD) joining Charles Schwab (SCHW) in cutting trading commission to 0%.

* GEOPOLITICS (HK/IRAN/NK): Overnight, North Korea fired a short-range missile over the East China Sea, which may have split into two, as one part of it reportedly landed inside the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), and another outside.  Japan’s PM Abe is to reportedly hold a meeting to decide how to respond as it violated UN resolutions. The White House is aware of the matter and is being monitored. Previously, when North Korea tested short range missiles, US President Trump seemed to have no problem with it. In terms of the missile specifics, it appears to be a submarine-based launch, and it was the longest-range weapon ever tested by the North Koreans, therefore seeming more alarming than previous missile tests. The missile tests come as US officials and NK officials are set to meet this week.

* BREXIT: The new plan is reportedly to keep Northern Ireland in the EU single market (for agriculture and manufactured goods) for four years, but not in the customs union. After four years, Northern Ireland lawmakers would decide whether they want to remain in that regime or align itself with the rest of the UK. Analysts say the plan essentially involves two borders: one between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland (given both parts would exist in different customs environments), and the other border with the rest of the UK, since NI would have different regulatory standards. The DUP are reported to be 'happy' with reports of the new plan; although DUP’s Dodd expressed concern on the regulatory divergence between UK and NI, stating nothing can be done in regard to the regulatory divergence between the UK and NI without Unionist consent, so it is "no change whatsoever". It had been reported that the EU would take its cue from Ireland on whether or not they would accept the proposals; sources familiar with the matter put a chance of the EU accepting the deal at 10%. Other outlets have suggested UK PM Johnson will offer an ultimatum to the EU: negotiate Brexit on the UK's terms within the next nine days, or face a no-deal divorce. The EU commission announced it welcomed UK PM Johnson's determination to advance Brexit talks and Juncker acknowledged the postie advances, notably to the regulatory alignment for control of goods entering Northern Ireland from Britain, however he said it will need further work in coming days, notably on the backstop. Juncker added that the delicate balance struck by the good Friday agreement must be preserved and another concern needing to be addressed is the substantive customs rules. Juncker reiterated the EU wants a deal and will remain united and ready to work to make this happen. Later on, the phone call between Johnson and Irish PM Varadkar was reportedly useful and constructive, although work still remains, adding the proposals did not fully meet the objectives of the backstop and that he would study them further and consult the EU.

* FX WRAP:

USD attempted a post ISM manufacturing recovery as it regained some ground overnight heading towards the 99.50 level, however gains were short-lived as the greenback turned course in the morning and continued to sell off throughout the rest of the session, breaking the 99 handle to the downside with a weaker ADP report doing little to slow the fall. DXY consolidates around the 99 level heading into Asia trade.

GBPUSD started the session on the backfoot, not helped by a miss in UK construction PMI’s. However, initial losses were pared and the cross traded relatively flat, hovering around the 1.23 handle as markets (and the EU) awaited Johnson’s proposal. Once the EU read the proposal, they seemed rather upbeat however did caveat their positivity by noting concerns still-remain about the deal, notably on customs and the backstop; cable remained glued to the 1.23 mark.

CHF: EURCHF rose by around a point on Wednesday, giving up some of its haven gains from the prior day, following the triple-whammy of factors including, comments from SNB’s Maechler, who reiterated the statement saying monetary policy must continue to be expansive given global uncertainty; inflation figures coming in rather soft, slowing to 0.1% - from a prior 0.3% - missing expectations for the pace and raising the ghost of deflation again; KOF Economic forecasts seeing GDP and CPI cut for both 2019 and 2020, forecasting a rate cut towards the end of this year due to upward pressure on the Swiss. Some desks noted that the Swissy’s move had the hallmark of SNB intervention.

Havens: Havens continued their bid today (apart from CHF on aforementioned reasons) amid a flight to quality following on from yesterday’s poor PMI data, and a weaker ADP employment report amid a poor global growth outlook, painting a rather grim picture ahead of Friday’s jobs report. JPY outperformed against the buck finding support just above 107 seeing lows of 107.06, rate differentials also likely benefited the JPY as US yields fall. XAU soaring today as the precious metal continued its rally finding highs above the 1500 mark at 1504, before consolidating just beneath the key psychological level heading into Asia trade.

EMFX: BRL opened weaker after the Senate approved the government’s pension reform bill with amendments. However, the Real ended on the front foot against the buck amid broad dollar weakness with the amendments on the bill to be presented later this evening.  ZAR also stronger against the Dollar, likely benefiting from the approval to split Eskom to help the electricity company. MXN little changed amid US House Speaker Pelosi highlighting progress on the USMCA deal.

* USMCA: US House Speaker Pelosi said that progress is being made in securing congressional approval on the USMCA trade deal, but stressed that there is still work to be done, particularly in areas of enforceability. US President Trump later hit out at the Democrat House Speaker, accusing her of being disingenuous about her reasoning for not moving forward with the plan.

analysis_details: • With risk assets continuing to suffer in wake of Tuesday's grim manufacturing ISM, energy futures were already trundling on the downside before accelerating into a sharp leg lower as the EIA weekly inventory data reversed bullish support after the surprise draw reported in the API data on Tuesday. The EIA reported crude stock building 3.1mln bbls (exp. 1.6mln bbls, and contrary to the API reporting a 5.6mln bbl draw). Products were more price supportive; gasoline saw a surprise draw of 0.2mln bbls, whilst distillates drew more than expected at 2.4mln bbls. Elsewhere in the report, net imports were little changed, US production ticked down to 12.4mln BPD (from 12.5mln BPD) and refinery utilisation fell by 3.4% (exp. -0.5%). As Saudi production concerns seemingly subside, the crude market is again fixated on its bearish direction in the overhang of Tuesday’s dismal manufacturing PMIs (globally) exacerbating demand concerns for energy (excluding Middle East conflict and a US-China trade truce); It is worth noting that next week will see US/China trade talks, so focus may shift back to the demand side, especially if negotiators strike a constructive tone), analysts are struggling to identify near-term bullish catalysts for crude benchmarks. Analysts aren’t decided on the downward price trend, however, for example Citi’s analysts say, “the expanded current supply/demand deficit off the Saudi production losses argues strongly against complacency regarding supply or a bearish price view,” with the question begging if whether the geopolitical risk premium needs revaluating on potential for more oil infrastructure attacks in the Middle East.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Yen and Franc flank G10 ranks, as Greenback tanks again
content:
JPY/CHF

The traditional safe-havens have diverged markedly, with the Yen making more ground at the expense of the Dollar in wake of a weaker than ADP survey that does not augur well for Friday’s NFP, softer US Treasury yields and ongoing global trade/geopolitical tensions following the WTO ruling in favour of Usd7.5 bn retaliatory US tariffs to counter EU subsidies for Airbus, more Iranian sabre rattling, another NK missile test and unrest in HK. Conversely, a bearish combination of weak Swiss inflation, downbeat KOF GDP and CPI forecasts and dovish SNB comments have undermined the Franc, with some market observers speculating that official intervention supplemented Maechler’s remarks about being ready to act. Usd/Jpy has pulled back further from recent 108.40+ peaks towards 107.25, while Usd/Chf rebounded to around 1.0025 before the Buck buckled again. Indeed, the DXY has retested support around 99.000 and a 99.091 Fib having attempted a post-ISM manufacturing recovery rally and fading just ahead of 99.500.

CAD 

Another marked G10 underperformer as the Loonie continued to reverse from peaks just shy of 1.3200 and almost turned full circle as oil prices extended their retracement in wake of EIA crude inventory stocks showing a big build in contrast to the API and more than expected. Usd/Cad got very close to 1.3300 and resistance just above the big figure at 1.3310, with Eur/NOK up through 10.0000 and Eur/SEK following suit on broadly risk-off trade, albeit the Swedish Krona not as badly shaken as its Norwegian counterpart.

EUR/GBP

The single currency and Sterling both benefited from the aforementioned Greenback reversal having waned in early EU trade, as Eur/Usd breached 1.0950 and Cable regained 1.2300 status awaiting more EU reaction to the last and potentially final proposal for alternative Irish border/custom arrangements from UK PM Johnson.

NZD/AUD

The Antipodean Dollars are ending a see-saw midweek EU session on a mixed footing as the Kiwi staged a firmer recovery from circa 0.6220 lows compared to the Aussie that faces psychological resistance at 0.6700 and ongoing US-China trade uncertainty in the run up to next week’s high level meetings in Washington.

EM

Broad gains vs the flagging Usd, as the Zar gathered momentum on ANC approval of plans to split Eskom as part of the latest aid plan and chart impulses when 15.4000 was tested, but not breached. Meanwhile, the Real overcame initial reservations after the Senate’s vote in favour of Brazil’s pension reform bill with amendments that will be presented later today. Similarly, the Try derived comfort on technical vibes when a rise over 5.7500 did not prompt follow-through buying or trigger stops and the Lira subsequently probed sub-5.7000 levels.

subject: Nomura say the global stock market cool down could last until 9 October
content:
• Nomura say that, going by the average pattern in global stock market sentiment that has historically unfolded after sentiment has fallen to more than one standard deviation below its rolling average, they expect the stock market cooldown to last through perhaps 9 October. The bank’s guage for US stock market sentiment deteriorated after the weak ISM Manufacturing reading yesterday, sliding from -2.3 on 30 September to -3.3 on 1 October, which is the most negative reading since 27 August. “Unease over the US economy has reared its head again just as the market has been backing away from its earlier undue optimism over US-China talks” the bank comments. 
  • Nomura argue that during these periods in which global stock sentiment is cooler, the market tends to react asymmetrically to the incoming news flow, becoming more sensitive to bad news than to good news. In this vein, they argue that the unexpectedly weak ISM manufacturing PMI reading announced yesterday was probably more of a catalyst for the stock market selloff yesterday than a genuine cause of it. Regardless, “we think investors would do well to stay on guard against a risk-off phase that we think may continue for as long as the cooldown in sentiment lasts” warns the bank.

What the slump in the ISM manufacturing PMI means for US stocks:

  • Nomura acknowledge the fickle nature of intraday moves in the US stock market in recent months, particularly in response to US/China trade related headlines. However, “the positioning of speculators at least seems to indicate that the underlying US stock market trajectory is pointing downward” suggests the bank, with “key points here are that global macro hedge funds have swung to taking profits on the long positions in US equities that they accumulated in July through September (while also swinging to staking out long positions in US bonds)”. Moreover, Nomura note that CTAs are still unwinding their long positions in US equity futures, with ES, NQ and YM futures all now undercutting the “trigger lines” (representing our estimates of where CTAs' long positions break even on average) at 2,970, 7,750 and 26,680 respectively.
  • The bank argues there are two implications of the manufacturing PMI reading. First; CTAs' net long position in S&P 500 futures has more room in which to shrink than it does in which to grow. CTAs' aggregate position in S&P 500 futures tends to correlate highly with US economic momentum, notes the bank, who interpret the correlation as a reflection of the fact that trends in fundamentals go a long way towards explaining the time series momentum of the stock market. Should October’s PMI reading match September, the bank calculate that their CTA position index should retreat further to -0.75 and +1.20 (from +1.4 currently), and the S&P 500 should hold in a range of 2,780-2,975. Secondly, Nomura argue there is the potential for a downward adjustment in the S&P 500; the bank notes that dividend yields have become dissociated from US manufacturing momentum and continue to pull away, meaning that share prices have not fallen far enough, or that the market's expected rate of return is parked at a low level. Theoretically then, “dividends ought to be higher than they currently are so as to compensate investors for taking on risk during a phase of market deterioration” the bank argues.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 2nd October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European equities are lower as sentiment remains subdued from yesterdays events and ahead of today’s risk catalysts
  • WTO are to announce the decision on the US' right to retaliate to against the EU over their Airbus (AIR FP) subsidies at 15.00 BST
  • EU Sources note UK proposals on Brexit as reported by the media "won't fly" and seem "fundamentally floored"
  • In FX, DXY has regained ground against most G10 peers while the debt complex has been choppy
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US ADP National Employment and EIA Weekly Crude Stocks, ECB’s de Guindos, Fed’s Harker, Williams, Evans, WTO Decision (10:00 ET), EU27 Ambassadors’ meeting

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets took the cue from the negative lead on Wall Street where the major indices declined on the first day of Q4 after US ISM Manufacturing PMI contracted to its worst level since June 2009. Losses in ASX 200 (-1.5%) accelerated after NAB shares tumble 3% amid an additional AUD 1.2bln charge relating to increased provisions for customer-related remediation, whereas upside in the Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) was limited by the unfavourable currency flow, whilst Toyota shares slumped due to poor North American vehicle sales and Sony remained near the bottom of the index after cutting streaming prices ahead of Google’s Stadia launch. Elsewhere, the Hang Seng (-0.2%) climbed off lows after returning from a long weekend, albeit oil giants remained pressured after Norway’s Sovereign Wealth Fund received the green light to sell USD 6bln worth of oil and gas stocks, meanwhile upside in the index was capped by the ongoing situation in Hong Kong as protestors vowed to step up action after a police officer shot a teenager yesterday. Meanwhile, South Korea’s KOSPI (-2.0%) was pressured after North Korea fired short-ranged projectiles towards the East Sea. As a reminder, Mainland China and Indian markets were closed today due to public holidays.

US

WTO are to announce the decision on the US' right to retaliate to against the EU over their Airbus (AIR FP) subsidies at 15.00 BST

Australia's Labor party is intensifying its demands for the Australian PM Morrison to release the transcript of a conversation with US President Trump, accusing the PM of cosying up to the US President at the expense of Australia's national interest. (ABC) As a reminder, this follows reports US President Trump pushed Australian PM Morrison for information to discredit the Mueller probe.

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea fired short-ranged projectiles towards the East Sea, Yonhap reported. Japanese Cabinet Minister Suga said the launch did not directly impact Japan but one North Korean ballistic missile landed inside the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and one outside. Japanese PM Abe condemned the North Korea launches and added that it violates UN resolutions. Further, Japanese PM Abe will hold a meeting of the National Security Council to decide how to respond to the projectile firings. In terms of details, South Korean Defence Ministry said the missiles launched by North Korea have a range of circa 1300km and was likely launched at a higher apogee to decrease range and could have been fired from a submarine. Japan has not yet determined whether North Korea's missiles were Submarine-launched ballistic missile and notes it may have been one missile which split into two. The White House said it is aware of the launch and is monitoring the situation. (Newswires/SCMP)

Saudi Arabia Foreign Minister said Iranian claims that Saudi Arabia has sent messages to the Iranian regime are inaccurate, WSJ's Summer Said reported. The Foreign Minister said, “Regarding what the Iranian regime’s spokesman referred to about de-escalation in Yemen, the Kingdom did not and will not talk about Yemen with the Iranian regime.” (Twitter)

UK/EU – Full Brexit Analysis available on the RANsquawk headline feed

UK PM Johnson will today unveil a new ‘two borders for four years’ Brexit plan which will leave Northern Ireland in a special relationship with Europe until 2025. Under the terms of the proposal, Northern Ireland would continue to follow all EU single market rules for agricultural and industrial goods until 2025, four years after the end of the ‘transition’ period in 2021. Elements of the deal (particularly the creation of two borders), are understood to have puzzled senior European diplomats and officials. (Telegraph) Irish Foreign Minister Coveney said if the Telegraph reports are true, it does not look like basis for an agreement, however DUP sources have confirmed that the party is largely “content” with the proposals, which are believed to still include a lot of elements of the backstop and  a “Stormont lock” which gives NI politicians a say in future EU rules. (Newswires/Guardian) Separate reports noted that officials and diplomats in Brussels are concerned that UK PM Johnson's plan has been specially designed to be unacceptable to the EU. (Times) UK PM Johnson says he has nine days left to negotiate a Brexit deal with the EU as on October 11th, the agenda will be set for the EU summit taking place on October 17th. (Sun)

Reports indicate the chances of a Brexit deal being secured are around 10%, and the DUP are supportive of the source report proposals. However, EU Sources note the only likely option for a Brexit deal prior to October 31st is to return to a NI backstop; otherwise likely a further delay which the EU would agree to. UK proposals as reported by the media "won't fly" and seem "fundamentally floored", and if this is the final plan, then discussion will move onto an extension on the Brexit deadline. (Newswires/Twitter)

Senior UK Government Official said the government is working for a new deal or a no-deal Brexit, there will be no delay. (Newswires) UK Downing Street is planning to prorogue parliament for three days next week to prepare for the Queen's speech on October 14th. (Sun)

UK Chancellor Javid is expected to delay the Budget until after October 31st amid uncertainty about whether the UK will leave the EU with a deal. (FT)

UK Markit/CIPS Cons PMI (Sep) 43.3 vs. Exp. 45 (Prev. 45). (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European Bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 -1.3%) are firmly lower, amid a lack of fresh bearish fundamentals, as the region more takes its cue from a negative AsiaPac lead; sentiment was downbeat overnight following Wall Street underperformance after bad US ISM Manufacturing data, the latest missile test launch out of North Korea and ongoing tensions in Hong Kong. Looking ahead, at 15.00 BST the WTO is expected to announce its decision on the US' right to retaliate to against the EU over their Airbus (-0.8%) subsidies, a potential source of impetus. Prior reports have suggested the ruling will allow the US to impose tariffs on roughly USD 8bln of EU imports on a wide range of products. Sectors are also firmly in the red; Materials (-2.1%), Industrials (-1.7%) and Energy (-2.0%) (despite slightly higher crude prices) are leading the sectors lower while Consumer Staples (-0.9%), Telecoms (-0.8%) and Utilities (-1.0%) hold up comparatively better. In terms of individual movers; Flutter Entertainment (+18.4%) shot higher on the news of the co.’s merger with Stars Group, pulling other betting names higher such as William Hill (+4.3%) higher in tandem. Nestle (-0.2%) shares are being supported by the Co.’s sale of its Skin Health unit. Tesco (+0.6%) managed to reverse early losses and now trades higher, after the co. released decent earnings premarket, but its CEO resigned. Pernod Ricard (+0.7%) is higher after being upgraded at Jefferies. Luxury names including LVMH (-2.0%) and Richemont (-2.1%) underperformed the market, with bad retail data out of Hong Kong (the largest decline on record) weighing.

FX

USD - The Dollar has clawed back some losses following yesterday’s abrupt U-turn from new 2019 highs in the DXY with the index bouncing firmly ahead of 99.000 towards 99.420, as attention switches to NFP via ADP and hopefully better news from the services side of the US economy after the more pronounced ISM manufacturing activity slowdown. However, the Greenback is also benefiting from renewed weakness in rival currencies and general risk aversion awaiting the WTO ruling on the extent that the US can counter EU subsidies for Airbus and repercussions in Brussels after UK PM Johnson delivers his latest/last Brexit proposal.

CHF/GBP - The clear G10 underperformers, with the Franc deflated on weak Swiss CPI grounds, further SNB guidance from Maechler expounding the virtues of NIRP allied to direct FX intervention and the KOF cutting growth and inflation estimates, while the Pound has been hit by a dire UK construction PMI and the ongoing political/Irish border wrangling. Consequently, Usd/Chf is back up near parity and Cable has recoiled from 1.2300+ towards Tuesday’s low only a few pips away from the big figure below, with the focus turning to Johnson’s appearance at the Tory Party conference from noon.

NZD/AUD - The Aussie and Kiwi are also unwinding/reversing post-US ISM manufacturing gains, as Aud/Usd returns to ytd lows circa 0.6670 and Nzd/Usd retests bids protecting 0.6200 alongside YUAN depreciation in holiday-thinned trade.

EUR/CAD - Holding up a bit better than most major counterparts, but some way off best levels vs the Buck as the single currency failed to sustain momentum through 1.0950 and Loonie could not breach 1.3200 amidst confirmation of more German GDP forecast downgrades and a downturn in crude prices.

JPY - Bucking the broad, if not overall trend, safe-haven demand/positioning has kept the Yen elevated between 107.90-55 against the Dollar, and from a chart perspective the 100 DMA in Usd/Jpy (now around 107.76) remains pivotal.

EM - Rand in the spotlight ahead of ANC judgment on the latest SA growth plan and following the SARB’s semi-annual MPR, with some technical support coming from a pull-back from 1 month peaks in Usd/Zar around 15.4000 to almost 15.3000 at one stage.

Goldman Sachs economists say the RBA's internal economic model suggests the Central Bank will need to release a USD 200bln QE programme to achieve its unemployment and inflation targets. (AFR)

FIXED

Some upside range extension for debt, with Bunds reaching 174.04 at one stage (-14 ticks vs -57 ticks at worst), Gilts up to 134.26 (-24 ticks from -69 ticks at the Liffe low) and the 10 year T-note rebounding to 130-27 from 130-14 at the other extreme, but the EU benchmarks still not following through even though stocks have extended losses. Hence, inverse asset correlations remain broken or fragile at best and divergence is emanating across the Atlantic divide even though demand for German Bobls was relatively strong and UK bonds are prone to regaining a no deal Brexit premium at the whim of any breaking headline that delivers a rejection from the EU to PM Johnson’s final offer.

COMMODITIES

The crude complex is mixed, giving away the majority of overnight gains, where the complex bounced from post US ISM Manufacturing data lows helped by a bullish headline API print, as risk sentiment took a turn for the worse at the European open. WTI and Brent currently sit just below the USD 54.00/bbl and USD 59.00/bbl levels respectively. To the downside technicians will be eyeing the USD 53.00/bbl handle in WTI; yesterday’s low and the late August/early September base. After yesterday’s choppy session, which saw Gold price swings of north of USD 40/oz, the precious metal is lacklustre and seemingly awaiting further macro drivers in the form of today’s ADP employment report, ISM Non-manufacturing tomorrow and NFP on Friday. In fitting with fragile risk sentiment, Copper remains under pressure as global growth concerns linger, albeit the red metal is off yesterday’s post ISM Manufacturing data lows.

API Crude Inventories -5.9mln (exp. +1.6mln, Prev. +1.4mln) (Newswires) API Cushing Inventories +0.37mln (Prev. +2.3mln) API Distillate Inventories -1.7mln (exp. -1.8, Prev. -2.2mln) API Gasoline Inventories +2.1mln (exp. +0.4mln, Prev. +1.9mln)

Russian oil production (Sep): 11.25MBPD (Prev. 11.29MBPD)., according to the Energy Ministry. (Newswires)

Iranian Energy Minister says he does not see a need for a emergency OPEC meeting, is a little surplus on the oil markets supply front adding the market is now in a normal situation. (Newswires)

IEA Chief Birol says the IEA sees 2019 oil demand at 1.1mln/BPD, though this may be revised. (Newswires)

  • We will allow the entire UK to withdraw from the EU, with control of our own trade policy from the start

ANALYSIS: PM Johnson’s Final Brexit Proposal – 12:00BST
content:
• 12:00BST PM Johnson is scheduled to speak just prior to the Conservative Party Conference closure.
  • Reports indicate that PM Johnson is expected to unveil his final Brexit plan, reports from the Telegraph indicate the proposal will be a ‘two borders for four plans’ plan, where Northern Ireland will remain as a special state until 2025; they will leave the EU customs union when the UK does, however, they will follow the EU in terms of rules regarding agricultural and industrial goods. The Telegraph noted that components of the deal, particularly the creation of two borders (regulatory Irish Sea border between Britain and Northern Ireland and a Customs Border between Northern and Republic of Ireland) has confused senior members on the EU side.
  • If these reports prove accurate, then the response so far has been discouraging. Irish Foreign Minister Coveney noted that these proposals do not appear to be the basis of a deal. Although, the DUP are reportedly pleased with these proposals.
  • From the EU side, consensus appears to be that they will not immediately respond to the proposals. And instead will spend a number of days discussing this with UK side before outlining their response. Sources with knowledge of the talks see the likelihood of securing a deal as very low, approx. 10%
  • Additionally, some commentary citing EU Diplomats and Officials has highlighted that PM Johnson’s plan has been designed to be unacceptable to the EU

Today’s Timings:

  • EC are expected to receive the UK proposals around time of PM Johnson's speech (12:00BST)
  • UK Chief Brexit Negotiator Frost will meet EU Commission Article 50 Task Force to present the text formally and host technical discussions
  • EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier will brief EU Diplomats on this. EU27 members will see the proposal text.
  • Barnier and EU Commission President Juncker will then discuss with the EU27 and determine if the proposals are sufficient to form the groundwork for intense negotiations or are insufficient

Looking ahead:

  • 11th October – Agenda to be set for the EU Summit, as such PM Johnson sees this as the last opportunity to negotiate a deal
  • 14th October – Indicative timing for Queen’s Speech
  • 17th-18th October – EU Summit
  • 19th October – Benn Bill deadline
  • 31st October – Current Brexit data

reaction_details: Earlier, reports suggested UK PM Johnson will today unveil a new ‘two borders for four years’ Brexit plan which will leave Northern Ireland in a special relationship with Europe until 2025. Under the terms of the proposal, Northern Ireland would continue to follow all EU single market rules for agricultural and industrial goods until 2025, four years after the end of the ‘transition’ period in 2021. Elements of the deal (particularly the creation of two borders), are understood to have puzzled senior European diplomats and officials. (Telegraph) Irish Foreign Minister Coveney said if the Telegraph reports are true, it does not look like basis for an agreement, however DUP sources have confirmed that the party is largely “content” with the proposals, which are believed to still include a lot of elements of the backstop and  a “Stormont lock” which gives NI politicians a say in future EU rules. content: The 10 year German benchmark has unwound all and a bit more of its late Tuesday gains made in reaction to a much weaker than forecast US ISM manufacturing survey, overall, with comments from outgoing ECB President Draghi underlining one of the main messages from the GC following September’s stimulus package – that fiscal policy is now the primary tool to arrest the economic slowdown/recession in some case and lift flagging inflation. Bunds kicked off Eurex at 173.86 and only managed a fleeting uptick to 173.89 before retreating further from yesterday’s 174.20 close to a 173.73 low, and the corresponding yield is poised to retest the psychological -50 bp mark ahead of Eur3 bn Bobl supply and more GC rhetoric courtesy of de Guindos.

**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

2nd October 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets took the cue from the negative lead on Wall Street where the major indices declined on the first day of Q4 after US ISM Manufacturing PMI contracted to its worst level since June 2009. Losses in ASX 200 (-1.3%) accelerated after NAB shares tumble 3% amid an additional AUD 1.2bln charge relating to increased provisions for customer-related remediation, whereas upside in the Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) was limited by the unfavourable currency flow, whilst Toyota shares slumped due to poor North American vehicle sales and Sony remained near the bottom of the index after cutting streaming prices ahead of Google’s Stadia launch. Elsewhere, the Hang Seng (-0.3%) climbed off lows after returning from a long weekend, albeit oil giants remained pressured after Norway’s Sovereign Wealth Fund received the green light to sell USD 6bln worth of oil and gas stocks, meanwhile upside in the index was capped by the ongoing situation in Hong Kong as protestors vowed to step up action after a police officer shot a teenager yesterday. Meanwhile, South Korea’s KOSPI (-1.4%) was pressured after North Korea fired short-ranged projectiles towards the East Sea. As a reminder, Mainland China and Indian markets were closed today due to public holidays.

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 2nd October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were negative and followed the lead from Wall Street, ASX 200 underperformed, Mainland China and Indian markets were shut
  • North Korea fired short-ranged projectiles towards the East Sea, one missile reportedly landed inside Japan’s Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ)
  • UK PM Johnson will today unveil a new ‘two borders for four years’ Brexit plan which will leave Northern Ireland in a special relationship with Europe until 2025
  • Irish Foreign Minister Coveney said the UK PM’s Brexit plan does not look like basis for an agreement, DUP sources confirmed that the party is largely “content” with the proposals
  • In FX, DXY held onto a bulk of its recent losses, JPY, EUR and GBP were flat, Aussie and Kiwi modestly outperformed
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK Construction PMI, US ADP National Employment and EIA Weekly Crude Stocks, ECB’s de Guindos, Fed’s Harker, Williams, Evans, UK PM Johnson, EU27 Ambassadors’ meeting and supply from Germany

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets took the cue from the negative lead on Wall Street where the major indices declined on the first day of Q4 after US ISM Manufacturing PMI contracted to its worst level since June 2009. Losses in ASX 200 (-1.3%) accelerated after NAB shares tumble 3% amid an additional AUD 1.2bln charge relating to increased provisions for customer-related remediation, whereas upside in the Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) was limited by the unfavourable currency flow, whilst Toyota shares slumped due to poor North American vehicle sales and Sony remained near the bottom of the index after cutting streaming prices ahead of Google’s Stadia launch. Elsewhere, the Hang Seng (-0.3%) climbed off lows after returning from a long weekend, albeit oil giants remained pressured after Norway’s Sovereign Wealth Fund received the green light to sell USD 6bln worth of oil and gas stocks, meanwhile upside in the index was capped by the ongoing situation in Hong Kong as protestors vowed to step up action after a police officer shot a teenager yesterday. Meanwhile, South Korea’s KOSPI (-1.4%) was pressured after North Korea fired short-ranged projectiles towards the East Sea. As a reminder, Mainland China and Indian markets were closed today due to public holidays.

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson will today unveil a new ‘two borders for four years’ Brexit plan which will leave Northern Ireland in a special relationship with Europe until 2025. Under the terms of the proposal, Northern Ireland would continue to follow all EU single market rules for agricultural and industrial goods until 2025, four years after the end of the ‘transition’ period in 2021. Elements of the deal (particularly the creation of two borders), are understood to have puzzled senior European diplomats and officials. (Telegraph) Irish Foreign Minister Coveney said if the Telegraph reports are true, it does not look like basis for an agreement, however DUP sources have confirmed that the party is largely “content” with the proposals, which are believed to still include a lot of elements of the backstop and  a “Stormont lock” which gives NI politicians a say in future EU rules. (Newswires/Guardian) Separate reports noted that officials and diplomats in Brussels are concerned that UK PM Johnson's plan has been specially designed to be unacceptable to the EU. (Times) UK PM Johnson says he has nine days left to negotiate a Brexit deal with the EU as on October 11th, the agenda will be set for the EU summit taking place on October 17th. (Sun)

Three EU sources stated the EU is not considering or have discussed a time limit on the backstop, however added that there are 27 countries and that they cannot rule out brainstorming outside of the EU formal process, according to The Guardian's Rankin. (Twitter) This follows sources reports that the EU is ready to consider time limit on Irish border backstop, considering a backstop for Northern Ireland only and reportedly sees possible concessions if the UK accepts backstop. EU27 Ambassadors will be meeting this afternoon, according to BuzzFeed's Europe Editor Nardelli. (Twitter)

Senior UK government official said the government is working for a new deal or a no-deal Brexit, there will be no delay. (Newswires) UK Downing Street is planning to prorogue parliament for three days next week to prepare for the Queen's speech on October 14th. (Sun)

UK Chancellor Javid is expected to delay the Budget until after October 31st amid uncertainty about whether the UK will leave the EU with a deal. (FT)

ECB's Weidmann (Hawk) said it is important that intensive discussions on far reaching measures such as government bond purchases are held, hoping decision will not lead to APP restrictions being called into question. Weidmann called for intensive discussions if it is to avoid pitfalls such as giving the impression the ECB is bankrolling governments. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS 

North Korea fired short-ranged projectiles towards the East Sea, Yonhap reported. Japanese Cabinet Minister Suga said the launch did not directly impact Japan but one North Korean ballistic missile landed inside the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and one outside. Japanese PM Abe condemned the North Korea launches and added that it violates UN resolutions. Further, Japanese PM Abe will hold a meeting of the National Security Council to decide how to respond to the projectile firings. In terms of details, South Korean Defence Ministry said the missiles launched by North Korea have a range of circa 1300km and was likely launched at a higher apogee to decrease range and could have been fired from a submarine. Japan has not yet determined whether North Korea's missiles were Submarine-launched ballistic missile and notes it may have been one missile which split into two. The White House said it is aware of the launch and is monitoring the situation. (Newswires/SCMP)

Saudi Arabia Foreign Minister said Iranian claims that Saudi Arabia has sent messages to the Iranian regime are inaccurate, WSJ's Summer Said reported. The Foreign Minister said, “Regarding what the Iranian regime’s spokesman referred to about de-escalation in Yemen, the Kingdom did not and will not talk about Yemen with the Iranian regime.” (Twitter)

FX

 

In FX markets, the DXY held onto a bulk of its recent losses after its slide from YTD highs down towards the 99.00 mark amid persisting weakness from the dismal US ISM Manufacturing metric. Thus, EUR/USD and GBP/USD have clung on to most of its Dollar-induced gains as the former hovered just below the 1.0950 level, whilst the latter meandered around 1.2300 ahead of PM Johnson’s formal unveiling of his final Brexit plan. Elsewhere, the JPY remained underpinned by the risk sentiment, with overnight focus on the geopolitical landscape as North Korea test-fired projectiles in which one reportedly landed inside Japan’s Exclusive Economic Zone. USD/JPY resided around its 100 DMA (107.76) with just under 1bln in options expiring between strikes 107.50-70 ahead of the pair’s 50 DMA at 107.05. Meanwhile, antipodeans are modestly firmer amid the Dollar’s demise, NZD/USD tested 0.6250 to the upside whilst its Aussie counterpart reclaimed the 0.6700 handle following yesterday’s fall to YTD lows (0.6670). 

Goldman Sachs economists say the RBA's internal economic model suggests the Central Bank will need to release a USD 200bln QE programme to achieve its unemployment and inflation targets. (AFR)

Mexico's Finance Minister said he is optimistic that the "New North American Trade Deal" will be ratified by US congress. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

 

WTI and Brent futures have recovered off the ISM-influenced lows as the benchmarks received a modest lift from the API crude inventory data which showed a surprise draw in headline crude stocks, albeit upside was limited as the internals were mostly bearish. WTI has reclaimed 54/bbl to the upside (ahead of its 50 WMA at 56.34/bbl), whilst its Brent counterpart regained USD 59/bbl+ status. Elsewhere, gold prices were uneventful after finding a base at 1460/oz yesterday, with the next level to the upside at 1496/oz (50 DMA). Meanwhile, copper benefitted from the softer Buck after the red metal price briefly saw one-month lows on the poor ISM metric.

API Crude Inventories -5.9mln (exp. +1.6mln, Prev. +1.4mln) (Newswires) API Cushing Inventories +0.37mln (Prev. +2.3mln) API Distillate Inventories -1.7mln (exp. -1.8, Prev. -2.2mln) API Gasoline Inventories +2.1mln (exp. +0.4mln, Prev. +1.9mln)

US

*US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 11 TICKS HIGHER AT 130-21: The TPLEX lived up to its haven status, disappointing US ISM data saw yields break lower as investors flocked into sovereign bonds amid US growth concerns jumping right back into the limelight and of such raising chances of further Fed accommodation. However, prior to the US session Fixed Income assets were on the backfoot, with JGBs leading the losses after a disappointing 10-year auction; desks were attributing the move as somewhat of a “taper tantrum” amid the BoJ’s latest efforts in reducing its bond purchases to steepen the curve. Fed’s repo operation was again undersubscribed in more evidence to easing liquidity conditions in money markets. By Treasury settlement the curve had bear steepened, no part assisted by growing market expectations of an October rate cut by the Fed, with the 2-year yield down by 6bps, 10-year yield down by 2bps, and the 30-year yield little changed.

Australia's Labor party is intensifying its demands for the Australian PM Morrison to release the transcript of a conversation with US President Trump, accusing the PM of cosying up to the US President at the expense of Australia's national interest. (ABC) As a reminder, this follows reports US President Trump pushed Australian PM Morrison for information to discredit the Mueller probe.

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asian markets follow suit from a downbeat lead on Wall Street
content: Asian equity markets took the cue from the negative lead on Wall Street where the major indices declined on the first day of Q4 after US ISM Manufacturing PMI contracted to its worst level since June 2009. Losses in ASX 200 (-1.3%) accelerated after NAB shares tumble 3% amid an additional AUD 1.2bln charge relating to increased provisions for customer-related remediation, whereas upside in the Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) was limited by the unfavourable currency flow, whilst Toyota shares slumped due to poor North American vehicle sales and Sony remained near the bottom of the index after cutting streaming prices ahead of Google’s Stadia launch. Elsewhere, the Hang Seng (-0.3%) climbed off lows after returning from a long weekend, albeit oil giants remained pressured after Norway’s Sovereign Wealth Fund received the green light to sell USD 6bln worth of oil and gas stocks, meanwhile upside in the index was capped by the ongoing situation in Hong Kong as protestors vowed to step up action after a police officer shot a teenager yesterday. Meanwhile, South Korea’s KOSPI (-1.4%) was pressured after North Korea fired short-ranged projectiles towards the East Sea. As a reminder, Mainland China and Indian markets were closed today due to public holidays.

content: • Link to article
analysis_details:
• Under the new policy, Japanese firms need to go through more complicated procedures to ship such materials to South Korea, including filing more documents.
  • Japan's export restriction is widely seen as a retaliation against a Seoul court's ruling last year that ordered Japanese firms to compensate victims of their wartime forced labor, during Japan's 1910-1945 brutal colonial rule of the Korean Peninsula. (Yonhap)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia follows suit to the downbeat performance on Wall Street after a dismal US ISM Manufacturing PMI release
content:
Asian equity markets took cue from the negative lead from Wall Street in which the major indices declined on the first day of Q4 after US ISM Manufacturing PMI contracted to its worst level since June 2009. Losses in ASX 200 (-1.4%) accelerated after NAB shares tumble 3% amid an additional AUD 1.2bln charge relating to increased provisions for customer-related remediation, whereas upside in the Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) was limited by unfavourable currency flow, whilst Toyota shares slumped due to poor North American vehicle sales figures and Sony shares remained near the bottom of the index after cutting streaming prices ahead of Google’s Stadia launch. Elsewhere, the Hang Seng (-0.9%) climbed off lows after returning from a long weekend, albeit oil giants remain pressured after Norway’s Sovereign Wealth fund received the green light to sell USD 6bln worth of oil and gas stocks, meanwhile upside in the index is capped by the ongoing situation in Hong Kong as protestors vowed to step up action after a police officer shot a teenager yesterday. As a reminder, Mainland China and Indian markets are closed today due to public holidays.

In FX markets, the DXY continues its slide from YTD highs down towards the 99.00 mark amid persisting weakness from the dismal US ISM Manufacturing metric. Thus, EUR/USD and GBP/USD have held on to a bulk of its Dollar-induced gains with the former eyeing 1.0950 to the upside, whilst the latter meanders around 1.2300 ahead of PM Johnson’s formal unveiling of the final Brexit deal, which sees a border in the Irish Sea and Northern Ireland following all EU single market rules for agricultural and industrial goods until 2025. Irish Foreign Minister Coveney said if the Telegraph reports are true, it does not look like basis for an agreement, although DUP sources have confirmed that the party is largely “content” with the proposals. Elsewhere, the JPY remains underpinned by the risk sentiment, with overnight focus on the geopolitical landscape as North Korea test-fired projectiles in which one reportedly landed inside Japan’s Exclusive Economic Zone. USD/JPY remains below its 100 DMA (107.76) with just under 1bln in options expiring between strikes 107.50-70 ahead of the pair’s 50 DMA at 107.05. Meanwhile, antipodeans are modestly firmer amid the Dollar’s demise, NZD/USD tested 0.6250 to the upside whilst its Aussie counterpart reclaimed the 0.6700 handle following yesterday’s fall to YTD lows (0.6670).
